update.description: Inactive joint controllers have default targets of `0.0`, which makes it difficult to distinguish between  inactive controllers and active ones with targets of `0.0` (issue #2307). This PR  addresses this issue by modifying the `JointControlWidget` to highlight the parameters for joint controllers that are active.
update.title: Joint control menu highlight active

content.raw:
@phorak , sorry for taking so long to get back to this. It works well for me.  The fact that the background becomes darker the moment the user changes values at least passes the idea that something is going on.

In the future, we could consider a more dynamic visual feedback, see for example how the text "pulsates" while a log is being recorded:

![recording.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2208107326-recording.gif)

But this is great as it is now. Approving!
content.html:
@phorak , sorry for taking so long to get back to this. It works well for me. The fact that the background becomes darker the moment the user changes values at least passes the idea that something is going on.

In the future, we could consider a more dynamic visual feedback, see for example how the text "pulsates" while a log is being recorded:

But this is great as it is now. Approving!

content.raw:
true, the checkboxes would give extra functionality, though a little more complexity

can you investigate the use of the `focusInEvent` to automatically `selectAll()`? if it takes more than 30 minutes to figure it out, we can file an issue for this and defer
content.html:
true, the checkboxes would give extra functionality, though a little more complexity

can you investigate the use of the focusInEvent to automatically selectAll()? if it takes more than 30 minutes to figure it out, we can file an issue for this and defer

content.raw: There is also the checkbox direction Louise mentioned in the PR comments if we would like to be able to individually disable joint controllers as well as see which ones are enabled/disabled.
content.html: There is also the checkbox direction Louise mentioned in the PR comments if we would like to be able to individually disable joint controllers as well as see which ones are enabled/disabled.

content.raw: `QDoubleSpinBox` doesn't have a `clicked()` signal. It does have a `focusInEvent`, which might work
content.html: QDoubleSpinBox doesn't have a clicked() signal. It does have a focusInEvent, which might work
That looks nice. Added in d56620c.

content.raw:
here's the patch I based that comment on:

* https://gist.github.com/scpeters/5cc962729b3262d5fa45c006cb1c59db
content.html:
here's the patch I based that comment on:

  • https://gist.github.com/scpeters/5cc962729b3262d5fa45c006cb1c59db

content.raw: that's a good point. it works ok if you use the scroll wheel, but if you just click on the box you can't see any of the text
content.html: that's a good point. it works ok if you use the scroll wheel, but if you just click on the box you can't see any of the text

content.raw:
Oh interesting, I think that would give the right idea! 

It might be a bit confusing when users click on the box and there is some text there though, maybe all the text gets selected the moment the user clicks on the box?
content.html:
Oh interesting, I think that would give the right idea!

It might be a bit confusing when users click on the box and there is some text there though, maybe all the text gets selected the moment the user clicks on the box?

content.raw: what if we make the text color match the background color if it's disabled (so it just looks blank)? I would only do it for the force and target boxes though; I'd leave the gains visible
content.html: what if we make the text color match the background color if it's disabled (so it just looks blank)? I would only do it for the force and target boxes though; I'd leave the gains visible

content.raw:
Ahh that's a tough one. I feel like the orange passes the idea of "active", but it might be a bit overkill. The dark on the other hand doesn't immediately give me the impression it is "inactive". This could all be just me though...

How about fading both the font color and the background  like this:

http://red-team-design.com/dist/uploads/2011/09/css3-buttons-inputs.png

I have a couple of worries about playing only with the color though:

1. It's not immediately obvious why the colors would be different in the first place, and there is no other clue to what is happening, like a tooltip or something
1. The inactive fields might end up looking "disabled", giving the impression that they can't be edited
content.html:
Ahh that's a tough one. I feel like the orange passes the idea of "active", but it might be a bit overkill. The dark on the other hand doesn't immediately give me the impression it is "inactive". This could all be just me though...

How about fading both the font color and the background like this:

http://red-team-design.com/dist/uploads/2011/09/css3-buttons-inputs.png

I have a couple of worries about playing only with the color though:

  1. It's not immediately obvious why the colors would be different in the first place, and there is no other clue to what is happening, like a tooltip or something
  2. The inactive fields might end up looking "disabled", giving the impression that they can't be edited

content.raw:
how about this? the darker color is when it is disabled.

[patch here](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/5cfbd0eb6cb6864f1606350402ccfe6f)

![joint_control_background_color.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3608182595-joint_control_background_color.png)
content.html:
how about this? the darker color is when it is disabled.

content.raw: actually, I want to try changing the background color...
content.html: actually, I want to try changing the background color...

content.raw:
It looks like you've changed the font color from black to orange when it is active. @chapulina how should we style the joint control widgets that aren't currently active?

I'm tempted to use solid black for the active state and a darker gray for inactive. I'll test and post a new image with my suggestion.

![joint_control_color.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2237277455-joint_control_color.png)
content.html:
It looks like you've changed the font color from black to orange when it is active. @chapulina how should we style the joint control widgets that aren't currently active?

I'm tempted to use solid black for the active state and a darker gray for inactive. I'll test and post a new image with my suggestion.
